awd_titl_txt: Wou-MMA: Particle Astrophysics with VERITAS and CTA
awd_abstract_narration:
This award continues an ambitious and diverse research program focused on high precision measurements of Galactic particle accelerators, which hold the key to the origin of the Galactic population of cosmic rays.  Over the past decade the VERITAS observatory has played a key role in opening the highest energy electromagnetic window on the Universe.  Gamma-ray emission reveals where relativistic particle acceleration happens, but the acceleration mechanisms, and the connections between the accelerators and the origin and properties of cosmic rays, remain unclear.  The study will exploit new capabilities of VERITAS and synergies with new facilities to search for potentially transformative new source classes.  This group plays a leading role in planning the next generation Cherenkov Telescope Array (CTA).  This award provides operational support for the group’s ongoing research and their role in the maintenance, operations and calibration of VERITAS.  This group mentors undergraduate students, engages local high school students, and gives public presentations to amateur astronomers and other interested groups.  They also work with the overall VERITAS outreach program, including conducting on-site tours, but the main outreach effort is a high energy astrophysics summer school for graduate students and post-doctoral researchers from around the world.

Targets for gamma-ray observation with VERITAS include a possible PeVatron, which may be the source of the highest energy Galactic cosmic rays, and a gamma-ray binary system at the peak of its 4.5-year super-orbital period.  New instrumentation on VERITAS, and new synergies with the Canadian Hydrogen Intensity Mapping Experiment (CHIME) radio telescope, will be used to search for optical and gamma-ray counterparts to the still enigmatic fast radio bursts.  The many VERITAS activities are all worthwhile, some are creative, and others are potentially transformative.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF award provided continuing support for the research activities of the University of Delaware gamma-ray astrophysics group. The group's research primarily uses data from the Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS), an array of four gamma-ray telescopes located at the Fred Lawrence Whipple Observatory in Arizona. We are also helping to develop a next-generation facility, the Cherenkov Telescope Array Observatory (CTAO).

Gamma-ray photons are produced in the extreme astrophysical environments associated with neutron stars, black holes, astrophysical jets and supernova explosions. When they interact in the Earth's atmosphere, they trigger a cascade of high energy particles which in turn produce a flash of blue Cherenkov light, lasting just a few billionths of a second. Gamma-ray telescopes record this brief flash, and use it to reconstruct the arrival direction and energy of the original gamma-ray.

Using VERITAS observations, the Delaware group has studied high energy emission processes from numerous astrophysical objects. Among these are candidates for the acceleration sites of the highest-energy Galactic cosmic rays: so-called "Pevatrons". These include objects first identified at high energies by Cherenkov telescope arrays like VERITAS, as well as more recently dicovered sources identified by particle detector arrays such as HAWC and LHAASO. We have also studied supernova remnants identified at lower energies by the Large Area Telescope onboard the Fermi gamma-ray space telescope, and gamma-ray binary systems consisting of a neutron star in orbit with a massive stellar companion. Outside of our galaxy Delaware researchers have explored the connection between X-ray and gamma-ray emission from the brightest gamma-ray emitting active galaxies, demonstrating that the emission is correlated down to minute timescales.

The Delaware group has also contributed to the maintenance, calibration and operation of the NSF-funded VERITAS array, and to the data analysis software tools which are required to interpret the observations. We have also developed a novel method for Cherenkov telescope calibration, which uses the light from satellite-based LIDAR experiments. The group is also involved with the technical and scientific development of CTAO: during this award period the PI concluded a term as science coordinator for the global CTAO consortium.

In collaboration with scientists from NASA Goddard, members of the group also organized an annual summer school in Delaware (the Fermi Summer School), which provides instruction to graduate students and post-doctoral scholars from around the world. Students are taught how to analyze gamma-ray observations, and provided with an overview of the astrophysical sources and processes which can produces such high-energy photons. We have also taken part in an annual masterclass for local high school students, in collaboration with the Delaware IceCube group.
